Historical Background

through the City, and an east-west route through the City. The
two City routes meet near the center of the City.

. Prior to passage of the Interstate Highway Act the proposed

expressway system could have been carried out only over a very
long period of years. With the 909 Federal financing provided
by the Act it suddenly became possible to visualize the construc-
tion of the main elements of a system within the foreseeable
future. This required, however, that the system be revamped to
conform to the approved Federal pattern. Two principal changes
were made in the 1949 Plan to bring about this conformity.

a) The West Radial in the 1949 Plan was extended to the western
City line via Leakin Park at which point it joins a proposed
expressway which would lead to Frederick. This extended
West Radial, plus the northern segment of the inner ring and
the East Radial, was now considered to represent the main
stream of cross-town traffic. Thus was born the present East-
West Expressway. It has little justification from the stand-
point of through traffic (there obviously being only a small
amount of Philadelphia-Frederick traffic) but makes a lot of
sense in terms of local traffic.

b) To provide the north-south route in the Federal plan the
Jones Falls Expressway was extended over the Inner Harbor
and then continued in a southwesterly direction to tie in at
the City line with a wholly new expressway to Washington.
This extension of the Jones Falls Expressway is referred to
as the Southwest Expressway. (The Master plan presently con-
tains two alternate routes for the Southwest Expressway. Sheet
6 only shows Alternate 2. Alternate 1 is not shown since it is
regarded as an unlikely possibility. As a matter of fact, neither

11

alternate is as helpful in handling local traffic as would be a
radial running more directly south in the direction of Glen
Burnie. The Planning Commission hopes that it can reopen
this question with the State Roads Commission at a later date.
If a relocation can be worked out it would not affect the recom-
mendations contained in this report.)

4. Creation of the East-West Expressway transferred the main
traffic flow to the west rather than to the southwest, but it was
still deemed advisable to retain the connection between the
Mulberry-Franklin-Pine-Myrtle block and the Russell Street via-
duct, both to provide the western segment of the inner ring and
as a means of tying the present Washington-Baltimore Express-
way in with the City’s expressway system. This connection was
not, however, part of the Interstate System.

5. The connection referred to in Item 4 above comes within a few
blocks of the Southwest Expressway. An expressway link across
these blocks was therefore added to the Plan thus providing a
southern closure of the inner ring some six to eight blocks south
of Pratt Street. The Pratt Street Expressway was then removed
from the Plan.

Events Since 1957

By the fall of 1957 design of the Jones Falls Expressway had pro-
ceeded to the point where it became desirable to have some agreement
with the State and the Federal Government on details of the interchange
between the Jones Falls Expressway and the East-West Expressway. It
was felt at the time that a complete interchange was essential permitting
all eight movements without resort to surface streets. The Department

ceeded to the point where it became desirable to have some agreement

was felt at the time that a complete interchange was essential permitting
